statement: The refactor-everything branch shows a viable pattern: stage-local workflows enqueue LLM requests based on sequential gating, while a centralized scheduler handles batch lifecycle. Reusing that separation (stage workflow vs scheduler) can simplify orchestrator cleanup without losing pipeline discipline.
rationale: Refactor-everything uses evidence workflows to enqueue requests per stage and a runs scheduler to poll/submit batches; this matches the desired separation of concerns and avoids window-specific coupling in llm_calls services.
keyAssumptions: Stage-local workflows can coexist with BaseOrchestrator
Current project intends to support multiple domain stages similar to refactor-everything
validationCriteria: Define clear boundaries: stage workflows enqueue requests; scheduler processes batches/jobs
Registry handles routing of apply-result/requeue across domains
Evidence flow uses sequential gating similar to refactor branch
critiquePoints: Architecture in refactor-everything may be outdated or incompatible with refactor-v2
Consolidating with BaseOrchestrator might reintroduce duplication
questions: Should BaseOrchestrator be retained or replaced with stage-specific workflows?
Which parts of refactor-everything are intentionally different from the current design?
